Neither boeing nor nasa need that precision, that's such a fallacy to believe ..
Nasa is using a controlled explosion to power their rockets, that's not a precise method. It's going to fluctuate a lot with stable inputs.
Boeing is similar, less chaotic but also not highly precise.
In both cases the precision happens by relative adjustments (relative to position of the craft) not by knowing the exact power of the engine.

So I've yet to see a real world use of that thing that wouldn't be possible if they have a much simpler approach with lower precision.

I have watched veritasium for years now, and have been amazed at how ell they manage to put complex scientific facts into comprehensive and concise video. However, this video has greatly dissapointed me, and tainted the reputation of the scientific community on youtube. This video claims that the 20 "masses" shown on screen make up the worlds heaviest weight at a total of 1,000,000 pounds, however the material of said mass is not specified. by observation alone, it is safe to say that these "masses" are either lead, steel, titanium, or an alloy of some sort. If we define a weight as a object capable of being moved relative to the earth (as the earth itself or, say, the entire continent of africa would not count as a weight),  the reality is that the heaviest documented movable object is not made of metal, but instead a combination of many different components, the ones constituting the most weight being water and trigylcerides. a triglyceride molicule is 3 fatty acids attatched to one glyserol molicule, creating what many refer to as "fat". fat in and of itself is an organic substance that forms a layer of insulation between an organism and the outside world, as well as storing energy for long term consumtion. you see, this collection of fat, water, and a bunch of other things is known by one name: your mother.

Dear America,

OK, I get that you like the old units. Fine, whatever, no point arguing about that. But why on Earth do you insist on using units that are on completely the wrong scale? Saying "This weights one million pounds" is like saying "Baltimore is one million feet from New York" or "the Great Salt Lake is one million inches wide." Nobody would do that -- it's insane and it doesn't let people relate those distances to other comparable distances. You guys had the good sense to redefine the ton to be 2000lbs instead of the random English 2240lbs, so you can easily just say "This weighs 500 tons." Why not do that?
Ngl having to still calibrate everything with kilograms and then convert everything to imaginary BS units truly cements the argument how genuinely stupid the imperial system is.

Seems like a lot of these comments are about imperial vs metric. 1) It's an easy conversion, the mass standard here is still cool and the same accuracy regardless of unit, 2) most people said "just use kg", but kg is a unit of mass not a unit of force, which is what they want, which brings us to 3) Even Newtons, which is the appropriate measure, means basically nothing to people familiar with kilograms, since in SI units it is kg m/s^2, or the amount of force required to accelerate a 1 kg object by 1 m/s^2. If you want to associate it with a ballpark mass in terms of downward force using g, you need to divide by 9.8 m/s^2, which is so much harder than just multiplying by ~2.5 to go from lbs to kg. Especially since they're using big round number increments.

Interesting area of research, but about the uncertainty we have for the constant for Newton's Law of gravitation? Currently the Newton constant of Gravitation is 6.67408x(10^-11) (+ or -) 0.00031x(10^-11) meters cubed, per kilogram per second as listed by the NIST but they are last updated in year 2014. There is also the problem in quantum mechanics and Einstein's theory of relativity that if you divide this Newton constant of gravitation by the reduced planks constant multiplied by speed of light both in the denominator, it will limit the number of significant figures for the speed of light and could potentially lead to a round up that will exceed the value for the speed of light at 299,792,458 m/s. Please do not round up, but simply truncate any calculations that involve the speed of light until this situation is corrected.
So I ask the people who work in the facility shown in the video, to how many significant digits of precision can you measure the Newton's constant of Gravitation and to what accuracy compared to the mysterious true value for Newton's constant of gravitation.

In the 60's Aero jet General Corp wanted to test the thrust of a rocket. They dug a deep hole in the ground near Homestead FL. They built a metal building over the hole and had a large overhead crane in the building. They built the rocket in the hole and filled it with solid rocket fuel. They installed a "lighter" on top of the upside down rocket. There were huge cables going to two huge concrete foundations. The building was on wheels and was pulled well out of the way before lighting the bottom end of the rocket which was facing upward. They lit the rocket, which blew the lighter upward, with such force, that it broke the cables or shackles. They never found the lighter.     The fuel was made in nearby low buildings with special walls between each work station in case of an explosion it would not kill all the people working on the line. There could be no oil allowed to get into the fuel. So the hoists in each station were run without oil or grease. They were 600 or 700 series MMM hoists Muskegan Mich. One of there lead guys came by my shop one day to borrow a jack for the operation. It was a 50 Ton hyd jack. aljenney@aol.com

Why not generate the required forces using hydraulics? It's a well-known principle that in hydraulic systems the force is proportional to the area - so for example, if the brake caliper in your car has a total piston area 5 times the size of the master cylinder/piston attached to the pedal, then the force exerted on the brake pads will be 5 times the force acting on the pedal.

So why not have a pair of hydraulic cylinders, one being 10,000 times the area of the other? For every 1lb. you put on the small cylinder you'll get 10,000lb. on the large one. Then you'll only need 100 lbs of carefully calibrated weight to calibrate the transducer up to 1 million pounds.

Alternatively, why not use levers? We all know force is proportional to distance from the pivot. So use a very long lever, put the transducer close to the pivot (say 1 foot away), and if you hang weights 10ft away, you'll be getting 10:1 amplification, so you only need 100,000lbs of weight. Use longer (or more) levers and you can get the same effect for less weight.

There are probably countless ways to get close to this accuracy using other accurate force-amplification methods.

pounds is a measure of force exerted. grams is a measure of mass. pounds ≠ kilograms in the sense that youre trying to compare mass because pounds is derived from kilograms and can fluctuate based on many factors like those stated in the video (bouyancy forces, different grav forces, etc) whereas kilograms is constant no matter how much gravity is exerted on you.
the only similarity is how we measure both of these quantities: by measuring the force an object applies on a sensor and then reverse the formulas for calculating such forces (i.e. dividing force applied by g to approximate a person's mass, in kilograms)

So sure, I wouldn't accepts an airplane built to 10% tolerances, because either it would crash or it would be a hideously expensive flight to cover the required overengineering, but I would accept (just pick some number) a 0.1% calibration chain, and 0.005% is just over the top. You probably get more than a 0.1% uncertainty just from random environmental variables on a flight. On a 300 ton airliner, 0.005% is 15kg, or 37 grams per passenger. That's on the level of how many farts each passenger is holding in. (Okay, I exaggerate.)

One of the many jobs I performed in my 20 years Naval service was in the Aircraft Intermediate Maintenance Department Physical-Mechanical Calibration Lab calibrating torque tools, pressure gauges and cable tensiometers used in ship and aircraft maintenance. All tools were on scheduled calibration cycles as were my test equipment which I had to deliver to an onbase lab for testing. So I began my Navy career at the Organizational level as an end user and later stepped up to mid-level calibration. After retiring I had a few jobs in Depot Level aircraft parts manufacturing and quality control and in the jigs used to make airframes.  Getting back to calibration, I had the occasion to test up to 1,000 foot pounds and 10,000 psi.
